text: 4 oz pour on draft at Spacebar. Black with light tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, roast, malt. Tastes of dark chocolate, licorice, malt. Medium body with a dry finish.
Pours a deep dark brown with a nice tan head. Chocolate/espresso aromas. Tastes just like it smells, deep coffee and chocolate flavors.
Bells rocks, and so does this beer that seems kind of intimidating to those who dont typically drink stouts. Its timid yet full of flavor. Id drink it again and again.

Very smoky scent and taste. Heavy and thick, like a fat black female NYC cab driver thats smoking with window barely cracked. Perfumed to mask the smoke but not working. Like the style, but shocked that this is an oatmeal. Was thinking it would have a touch more sugar and less bitter. Still enjoyed, and think that Bells needs a better name on this baby. Maybe ABW Smoky. Tap
Tap at Ginger Man, New York. Colour is black with brownish head. Aromas and flavours: Coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Very soft.

Draft pour at the source. Pours a darker brown with a beige head of foam. The aroma has that sweet oath, toasty taste I love in oatmeal stouts. Moderately sweet, but toasty. Medium body, velvety mouthfeel, and moderate carbonation..

On Draught
Pours basically black with a decent head and some lacing on the glass.

The aroma is roasty & chocolaty. Its got some caramel and some light sweetness. Clean, inviting, and rich all around. 

The flavor is rich & roasty with a nice mild sweetness. The bitterness is moderate and well employed giving a sensation of dark chocolate and coffee. 

Just sort of real stouty. Simple and enjoyable.

Tap @ Bells: Deep, rich black color, almost oily with a foamy film that builds up on top with a nice chunky collar laced around the edges. Creamy oat forward aroma, light milk & cream sweetness with soft cocoa nibs, bakers chocolate, & hints of caramel-like sweetness. Flavor contains a bit more roast & even some light coffee bean, although the presence of semi-sweet, creamy oats is still very much the front runner. Milk chocolate & oats play well with a leafy & lightly earthy hop profile. Finished with notes of chocolate covered burnt grains. A nice & easy drinking stout.
Another A+++ stouty from this brewery....perfect aroma of coffee and roast. Flavor is so smooth and rich with carmel and malt expressions. Finishes not too malty, but awrae that its there. GREAT
Mmm stouty! I got this at a tap takeover because I had never heard of it before... Its great, one of those stouts that has that stouty creamy attitude but still manages to be somewhat refreshing.

On tap at Tap and Mallet Total Tap Takeover. This one had to go after some other world class Bells beers, thus its rating will suffer. This one falls short of world class and the standards of oatmeal stout IMHO, but is still a decent beer. Rocky foamy head. Thick. Nose is cocoa and powered. Mouthfeel is a bit dry, odd for a sweet stout.
Bottle gift from SJ. Nice notes of chocolate malts, roast, coffee, and oatmeal. The body was a bit too thin for the way I like my stouts, but it was stil a well-blended brew.
Bottle at the Triad bottle share at Foothills organized by Mike. Black pour. Moderate roast, slightly chewy, and rich of chocolate. Appropriate level of sugar sweetness. Solid oatmeal stout.
On tap at tap house. Black thick pour light head. Aroma of chocolate malt. Taste is a slight sweet slight bitter chocolate stout. Reminds me of a lift breakfast stout.

Draft at Bells. Pours black with tan head. Lots of chocolate and dark fruit in the nose. Taste is earthy oatmeal, sweet/roasted malt, chocolate. Nice sweetness but not overly so for a "Sweet Stout". Heavy body, rich and warming.
Taste of coffee, dark chocolate, and oats. Dry smooth finish, with medium carbonation. On tap at eccentric cafe. Deep black with a disappearing off white head.
Solid stout as always. So damn smooth and drinkable. Great roasted malts balanced with notes of chocolate and oat.

draft sampler poured almost black but very dark brown with mocha head and lots of lacing. the aroma is lots of roasted malts and chocolate..the flavor is creamy smooth...lots of deep dark roasted malts with chocolate and this full bodied beer just slides down. another excellent example of a stout brewed by bells...
Tap at Bells - pours pitch with a dark tan head. Aroma is subtle coffee toastiness. Taste is sweet with a touch of lingering bitterness. Palate is both sticky and dry. Nice!

On draft at the Eccentric Café. The pour is a darker brown, some reddish hints and a thin head that lingers as a film with decent lacing. The aroma is pretty bland with the roast and the oats. The flavor is sweet, playing into the oats and the roast tends to fade out. The body is light and the finish is sweet and dry

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is light oatmeal, some sweetness but pretty weak. Appearance is dark black, light tan head. Taste is mediocre, sweetness compared to a Guinness with more flavor, caramel, toffee, finishes somewhat bitter. Mouthfeel is nice, thick with soft carbonation. Overall, a bit disappointing but I have definitely had worse.
Draught at Bells. Dark pour light head that dissipated. Light roasty aroma. Mild bitter roasted malt flavor. Mild oatyness.

On tap at Bell's 3/31/13. Malty aroma. Not too dry and not too sweet. Good flavor. A bit of coffee on the back end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft.  Light oat and chocolate malt aroma.  Black with moderate head.  Sweet chocolate and oatmeal malt and mildly bitter herbal hops flavor.  Nice hoppy stout.

Draft to taster at the Eccentric Cafe. Looks good for the style; a semi-opaque black with beige lacing. Smells sweet with notes of dark malt and oats. Tastes like it smells with a touch of roast and a nice mouthfeel. Good beer.

On tap during the Bells Eccentric Cafe Day at the Hungry Monk. Pours a very dark brown with a creamy beige head. Aroma of very dry grains and a touch of biscuit. Malt forward as an oatmeal stout should be with smooth oats, some peanut butter, and toast. Dry mouthfeel, medium body. Decent oatmeal stout.

Draught in savannah.  Not a great pour but nice and smooth.                     

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draft at Devils Advocate in Minneapolis. Pours a dark, dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma is roasty, nutty, toast. Medium to heavy on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, roasty, coffee, nutty, with a toasty finish. Not a sweet as Double Cream. Very tasty. Shame its not bottled.

Draft sample. Black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of dark chocolate syrup, caramel, and a bit of coal. Flavors are of more dark chocolate, oatmeal, roast, and sweetish pale malt. Heavy bodied, with the roasted notes providing balance. Very satisfying.

Sampler pour on tap at All Stouts Day 2012 (Kalamazoo, MI). Pours a rich deep blavkish pour, good hazy dark middle. Richer hues, a touch of brownish hue on the bottom and edges. A bigger light brown head was good sized, a frothy ringing layer laces ok. Aromas offer gentle sweetness, oatmeal and biscuit. Cocoa, toffee, and gentle sweetness. Touches of biscuits, earth, and gentle sweetness. Dark but a slight bit sweet. Initial is medium bodied, a bit lighter with cocoa and biscuits, some toffee. Oatmeal, dark grains, and gentle toasty roast. Some cocoa, oatmeal into the middle give. Bit of body, touches of sweetness. Dryness, gentle toast, lingering cocoa. Touches of mellow body, really solid Oatmeal Stout. It gives a touch of body, gentle roast, sweetness provokes some good vibes, doesnt get overdone. Solid.

On tap at Eccentric Cafe.  Served in a 16oz imperial-like pint glass.  Pour was completely black, head was white but not very substantial.  Smells like oats and vanilla but very faint.  Medium mouth feel with relatively low carbonation, and a bit tangy.  Bitter oat-y taste with some malt and vanilla mixed in.  Pretty low-key, nothing outstanding but solid and good.  Finish is all vanilla.

Draft. Poured a black color with a large frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted chocolate malt aroma. Medium to heavy smooth sweet chocolate flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is a very good beer.

On tap at a Bells tap takeover.  Big frothy fast dissipating head.  Aroma is roast with just a touch of oats and chocolate smell.  Has a medium body.  The taste is flavorful but mellow.  A bit sweet and dry far from a heavy oatmeal taste.  Nice smooth creamy finish.  With I could get this in bottles regularly.

Bottle 12fl.oz.[ Courtesy of Secret Summer Santa ]. Clear dark dark brown colour with a average, frothy to creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dark chocolate, dusty, moderate oat, sod notes. Initial flavour is light heavy sweet, light light acidic and moderate bitter, finish flavor is moderate sweet, light light acidic and moderate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration, dry, light light berry acidic. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120211]

Location/Date:Draft at Bells Beer Dinner @ RFDs, January 10th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours black with light brown head. 
Aroma: Aroma is of malt, coffee.
Taste: A lot of coffee, malt, faint oatmeal.
Palate:Light-medium body, light aftertaste.
Summary: This is one of my favorite non-imperial stouts.

I dug this one, big time....has a really pleasant chocolaty body without being too heavy, some decent hops on the backside, and an overall great taste.  Its not too heavy, but I wouldnt call it a thin stout either.  IT has surprising body for the low alcohol content.
On tap at Bells. Now this was a tasty little treat. Medium bodied, nice and sweet. Even alongside the bigger stouts, this one held up on its own. Easy drinking, but plenty of character. Nice.

Glass at the Bells tap takeover at 4th Street Patio on 10/12/11. Excited to try this one again because its been 3 and a half years since the first and only time Ive had it. Pours black with a thick brown chocolate milk head. Aroma is chocolate, cream and coffee bitterness. Roasty malt flavor with chocolate and cream before a bitter coffee finish. Think of Kalamazoo stout a little sweeter or Double Cream Stout a little roastier. Tasty!
Tap at Maduro in Madison, WI. Dark brown pour with a creamy head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted oats. Smooth palate. Taste is creamy chocolate and light roast. Some milky sweetness. Awesome.
A real solid oatmeal stout, or stout that is, the oatmeal part is pretty trivial in most if not all oatmeal stouts.

Served on draft at Maduro in Madison, WI at the GTMW pre-party. Pours a very dark brown color with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of big roasted malts, nuts, oats and smoke. The taste is rich roasted malts, coffee, oats, nuts and a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied. Damn good.

On tap at Bells. Aroma: Intense burnt toast and dark chocolate. Sublime. Appearance: Pitch black, small brown head. Taste: Oats is nicely integrated with the caramel and maple sweetness. Palate: Full bodied, light carbonation. Very smooth. Overall: One of the oatmeal stout Ive had.

On tap at MBGSF 2011.  Pours a deep brown with a light tan head.  Roasty coffee aroma with brown sugar.  Flavor is quite roasty, coffee, with brown sugar, definitely an anise flavor, some dark chocolate.  Reminds me a lot of Kalamazoo Stout.  Quite nice.

On tap; pour is dark brown with a hint of amber; mild,  off white head in this glass with very mild lacing. The nose is fruity, roasty, and chocolate really. The flavor profile is where this one really shines. The oats, chocolate, caramel, and roastiness fuse in a silky smooth manner, this is a light bodied sweet stout that I really enjoyed

Date: June 27, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Bells, Kalamazoo, MI Appearance: Dark brown with medium amount of head Aroma: Coffee/Chocolate/Oats Flavor: Consistent with aroma and dry roasted Other: Enjoyed this beer, though not quite as much as the Porter but it was very close.

Draft at Rich Os. Deep brown body with a beige head, mostly diminishing. the aroma is sweet with notes of roasted malts, chocolate, smoke and vanilla. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture and moderate carbonation. Nice tastes of smoke and roasted, but not burnt, malts, oatmeal. Easy drinking and nicely done.

(sampled at Daks Memorial Day tasting.  Growler courtesy of Mike via Justin.  Thanks guys!).  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Aroma had oatmeal, chocolate and caramel.  Taste was sweet malt and roasty bitterness.  Thin bodied with a slick texture.   Smooth finish.  A decent, easy drinking beer.

From keg by way of growler, tasted at Daknoles Memorial Day "Throw Down".  Thanks Mike.  Pours dark brown/black, with light brown head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee, which overpowers the oats.  Some licorice.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, roasty and creamy.  Nice long dry finish.  Nice stout, but not extraordinary.  I prefer the Expedition Stout myself.
Dark cocoa, roasted nuts, and malt.  Lots of dark malt and chocolate.  A bit watery.  Expected more.
Dark brown, tan head.  Nice creamy oats aroma, chocolate, coffee.  Flavor is creamy, oats, chocolate.  Good stuff!

12oz pour at Meridian Pint.  Watery opaque black with a thin, lacing, tan head.  Mild malty aroma, sweet, nutty, light bread.  Flavor is sweet, molasses, a little licorice, malty, bready.  Medium bodied and dry.  Reminder me of a less sweet Kalamazoo.  Easy drinker, but a lot like their other offerings.

On tap at Nimbus brewing in Tucson 
Appearance: Black with a nice big tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Dark malts and candy 
Taste: Dark malts, sweet candy and coffee 
Nice mellow stout, easy to drink.

Location: Bottle at Max and Andys Fantasy Tasting, 5/1/10


Aroma: The nose is chocolate malts, oats, earth, and a touch of over-ripe fruit

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head a top it

Flavor: The taste is deeply malty, oatmeal, chocolate, and fruit, with a dry finish

Palate: The body is medium, it is somewhat chewy on the mouth with a solid finish to it

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty good beer, it was a little past its prime, but still quite good.  Id like to try this one again when it is a little fresher, but I still enjoyed it.
Had on draft at the brew pub.  A pretty basic stout that is easy on the palate.  Overall, not too shabby.

Pours deep brown on tap with thin tan head, big roasted, chocolate, nutty aroma.  Taste up front is oatmeal, chocolate, leading into a nutty middle with a roasted dry finish.  Very nice, balanced, and tasty oatmeal stout.

[Tap] Had this at an event and a couple of smokers were nearby, so Ill do the best I can on this rating. The beer was the typical dark brown stout with a smallish brown head. The aroma was really simple with lots of roasted malts, moderate sweetness from the oats, coffee, and a little chocolate. This beer is really nothing remarkable in its uniqueness, but everything is just in fantastic balance. Chocolate, coffee, bittersweet roasted malts, everything you would expect. Fabulous stout. Wish I could find it everywhere.
Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting - arouma is oatmeal and chocolate, roasty malts. This beer would be so good if it was a little younger, but this bottle has some oxidation on it.
Bottle at Fantasy Tasting.   Dark brown with flat head.  Roasted oxidized chocolate coffee aroma.  Coffee chocolate with oxidized dark fruit and wheat tang.  Pretty good but past its prime.
The aroma is vegetanle, earth, oats, chcoolate.  The flavor is the same.  The appearance is deep brown, tan head.  The finish is slight hop bittering.  Medium in body.  Very nice stout.

Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting.  Pours a lightly hazed brown, small white head.  Nice soft oatmeal sweetness and a bit of cherry.  Medium bodied, nice chewy malt, chocolate. Finishes with a little more chocolate pudding.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2010 Bottle (pre-batch numbers) Past its prime, unfortunately. Pretty thin but only slightly oxidized.Very dark black with just a bit of head. Semi sweet and pretty dry. Drinkable but really a shell of a beer. Ill have to catch it on tap one of these days.
Re-rate:
On tap. Still thin and dry with a slight acidic taste to it. Surprised about the body on this one, but the oatmeal treatment does seem apparent.

(Draught)  Pours an opaque black body with an aggressive tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, oatmeal, roasted grain, and some mustiness.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, and oatmeal.  Reminds me some of my chocolate power smoothies.
4oz draft sample - Aroma of chocolate and oatmeal.  Flavor is creamy chocolate, oats and roasted dark malts.  Palate is creamy and lush.  A very nice oatmeal stout.

Pre Great Taste, Maduro, Madison. It had been quite some time since I last had this, and I remember the fall stouts from Bells with much fondness. Id like to see Bells take this in a bourbon barrel direction, as this would lend itself well to this beer. THe nose is not overpowering. The palate is chewy, a bit roasted, with notes of cocoa powder and cream. Finish is chewy and drying. A solid sipper.

draft at maduro (pre GTMW)...pours an oily almost black pour with a thinnish light beige head... aroma of roasty cocoa where you could almost sense the earthy oat texture.... roasy light chocolate flavors with subtle bitter notes in the finish.  nice creamy mouthfeel

2006 Bottle. Sent as an extra in trade with Puddintane. Thanks! Black color with clear dark brown edges and a nice reddish hue. Initial light tan head settles quickly to a bubbly ring around the glass. Sticky sweet fruity nose, with tones of raisin bread, chocolate and plenty o oats. Nicely balanced flavor that is both sweet and bitter. Dark chocolates stand out with a touch of coffee grounds. Oatmeal comes through more in the finish. Creamy texture, very easy to drink. Totally sessionable!

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 Rerated on tap at Eccentric. Changes between this fresh on tap and way old in the bottle are only for the better. This is still stouty looking, but aromas are full of licorice(??!!), coffee and leather. Flavor is the same with that really odd anise flavor that at times comes off as a bit bourbony.  Good... Very good.  

Original rating:
Pours a dark brown with little head and aromas of chocolate and oats. Flavor is pretty similar with a little oxidation, but is good after this many years.  Of the two bottles Ive had, one was bad and the other was good.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: [Draft @ Eccentric Cafe] Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, flaked oats, cocoa, toffee, and some vanilla.  Taste of roasted malts, light coffee, cocoa, vanilla cream, and an oatty, creamy mouthfeel.
Tap @ Eccentric Cafe. Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, oats. Flavour of dry coffee, roasted malts. Medium bodied. Slightly bitter finish.
Draught at the Eccentric Cafe 05/03/2009.  Opaque dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Nice full lacing.  Roasty chocolatey with some nice charred malt to it.  Finish is dry coffee bitter.

On tap at the Eccentric Cafe 4/13/09. Pours a Deep brown/black with a minimal but well lacing tan head. Good aromas of chocolate, roasted malt and oat. Flavor is mostly the same with some mild coffee, light hops and fruit, and all around goodness. Finishes with a light bitter that clings to the back of the tongue and refuses to go down(read: good thing). A small presence of alcohol floats in and out throughout the taste. Creamy loveliness with a medium carbonation. Fantastic.

Draft and bottle. Pours a black body with a tan head.  Huge malt profile, chocolate, coco, some creamy milk chocolate with a sweet malt body and some thin coffee bitterness.  Vanilla and oat accents.  Good brew.

On tap.  Pours dark brown/black with a small tan head.  Nice aroma on this.  Smooth, roasty, milk chocolate, oats, and a lot of coffee.  Taste is the same, creamy, smooth and slick with a nice balance of all the flavors and nice full mouthfeel.  This reminds me a lot of the Kalamazoo Stout.  This was excellent.

Draft:  Poured at the Eccentric Cafe, this was a dark mahogany with a medium sized white/cream head.  Notes of brown sugar, chocolate malt and some mild coffee hints come through in the nose along with a bit of oat.  Medium-bodied mouth feel leads to a dry, chocolate based flavor with some notes of vanilla and oat.  Good stuff.

12 oz bottle shared by iowaherkeye. Thanks Joey. Poured an opaque black color. Head was light brown. Big malty aroma with lots of molasses accented by vanilla, chocolate, anise, and raisin. Assertively roasty up front and relatively sweet. Full bodied with chocolate, coffee, and raisin flavors. Another great stout by Bells.

On tap at Eccentric Cafe.  Notable in its very smooth mouth feel with no bitter after taste.  Not too roasty for a stout, which helps maintain that smooth body.  Surprised to see its retired?-- since I just had it on tap.

On tap at the Eccentric Cafe.  Deep chocolate brown, silky in body with ruby edges.  Aroma of honey grahams, rich chocolate mousse, some burnt caramel and vegetal tones from full roasted coffee notes.  Smooth and deliciously creamy; a dense doughy core of cinnamon bread, vanilla, and brown sugar.  Lots of maple granolas, chocolate milkshake and heavily creamed coffee.  Robust and delicate at the same time.  Medium bodied, bold, and rich, while still understated and suffering not the slightest wink of black malt astringency that so commonly afflicts the oatmeal stout.  Black licorice in a flourish of new sweetness in the finish.  Without exception the best of its class.

Date: 12/15/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

dark brown, thin tan head, sweet roasted and chocolate aroma, creamy body, rich malt flavor, light roasted and lots of chocolate, 
-------- />
Date: 04/28/2006
Source: brewpub

same as it ever was

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *4

Solid opaque black pour, booming tan head with great retention. The nose is writhing with roasted malt and coffee notes. Also noted are molasses, oats, anise, milk chocolate, nuts and just a touch of sugar. Alcohol is not detected, nor are any flaws. The flavor is highly sweet, moderately bitter, with medium acidity and a roasty tang that lingers. Coffee and roast are perfectly integrated, even in such quantity. the finish is sweet, roasty and sugary, with grains, anise and chocolate lingering. The mouthfeel is extraordinarily smooth, medium-full bodied and slick. Delectable.

Bottle shared by sliffy. Black pour with a light tan head. Aroma of light toasted malt, oats, brown sugar, bitter coffee/chocolate and a bit of cinnamon. Flavor of brown sugar, light bitter coffee and roasted malt...chocolate as well. Medium body...bitter and roasty with a bittersweet/roasty finish. Nice stuff.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a very dark brown color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Sweet, syrupy aroma: chewy nougat and toffee, with some lightly toasted marshmallow.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: dense, toasty malts and milk chocolate; beautifully balanced level of sweetness, with chewy nougats and toffee - dense, slightly viscous, and damn good.  Lengthy, dry chocolate finish.  Theres a great floral / dried fruit note permeating the whole package; this is still in great condition after five years (Ive been told it lived in a gas station fridge in Flint...).

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Black body with a small dark tan head. The aroma is milk chocolate, molasses, oats, toffee, lightly vinous with some berry. The flavor is lightly sweet, lots of roast, oatmeal, milk chocolate, raisinss and toffee. Medium body is soft with light/moderate carbonation and a rich roasted finish. This has held up amazingly well. Thanks Brad.

hazy brown body with no head..aroma has hints of sweet caramel malts, nuts, and chocolate..flavor is nicely toasted, with oats, sweet chocolate, light bread..very full-bodied beer that finishes slightly bitter and dry

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2008 Bottle thanks to Silphium: Poured black with a small tan head. Aroma, roasted malts, chocolate, some oats, molasses, and some ever so faint oxidation. Flavor, chocolaty and sweet, some oats, roasted malts, dark fruits, really nice brew. 

On tap @ Brews Cafe: Didnt take notes, but very rich, creamy palate, oats, chocolate, roasted notes. Really confirmed what I thought of it, and nice to finally have a fresh sample of it.

A brown beer with a very fast disappering brown head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of chocolate, but also light hints of alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with quite strong notes of chocolate, and lesser notes of roasted malt, which also lends a bit of sourness to the beer, vegetables, spices, and oatmeal. Quite nice.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Clear, dark orangey brown with a beige head. Lightly vinous with aromas of hard roasted malt. Medium body with rather dry, roasted malt and some notes of dried fruit. Lightly burned, bitter finish. 290806

Bottled. Reddish brown coloure. Brown head. Light roasted and sweet aroma. Some coffee notes. Flavour as well roasted and coffeeish. Light alcoholnotes annd fruitsweetness. A bit band. Medium bodied. Roasted bitter end with light alcohol notes. Thanks to Suiiy for the trade.
Bottled. Dark brown coloured. Soft coffeeish and fruity aroma. Sweet milk chocolate flavour. Light to medium body.

2002 Bottling thanks to Mr. Styles!  Poured a big, beautiful, deep brown with an inch or so of medium-density yellowish-toffee head.  Nose is quite enjoyable, and has certainly changed form over the years... picked up a tart dark fruity/licorice component to compliment rich dark and milk chocolates, lactose, and roasted espresso.  Flavor balance was skewed a tad too far in the direction of heavy dark fruit skin tartness, but still maintained composure with a solid cocoa, espresso, and lactose middle.  Bitterness was mild and coffee-centric.  This was still creamy and smooth on the palate after what... 3.5 years or so?  Larry.. dawg.. if you bottle this again, Ill buy a case.

Bottle: Dark brown, nearly black, moderate fizzy beige head, spotty lacing.   Soft roasted malt nose, slight sweetness, but also quite a bit of sourness, fruit skin, and cocoa.   Somewhat dry tart fruit skin flavor to start, roasted malts are softer than suggested by the nose.   Slight bittersweet cocoa like finish, remaining semi-sweet and tart, with lingering fruit skin.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full.   Not as heavy or lactose oriented as other examples.   Definitely more tart and dry than I am use to.   Still enjoyable tho.   Founders and Lost Coast still take the cake, in my opinion.   Thanks to CaptainCougar and Styles for each providing me with a bottle!

Draft @ Bells Eccentric Cafe:  Very dark brown that is mostly opaque with a small tan head.  Big huge roasted malt and chocolate.  Light notes of coffee grinds.  Very roasty flavor with dark chocolate left in the mouth on the finish.  Light bitterness on the finish.  Almost creamy mouthfeel.  CO2 is light.

Pours a velvety black into the glass with a thin tan head on top. The foam dissolves quickly leaving behind a few spots of lace and a thin ring around the surface. A roasted malt aroma of chocolate and coffee with a hint of nuts greet you before each sip.This medium bodied beer is smooth and very drinkable. The flavor is mainly chocolate and coffee, but it doesnt overpower the taste. It finishes with some earthy, nutty flavors leaving behind a coffee taste.
I found this to be a very drinkable stout whos flavor doesnt overpower the palate.

Old bottle from perhaps 2002 or earlier, Sampled February 2006
Pours with a frothy, reasonably fast disappearing, light brown colored head.  The beer shows a bright, clear deep brown color as I pour it, but otherwise sits an opaque black color in my glass.  Ah the aroma is quite nice, it has that characteristic note that develops in lightly oxidized stouts.  Heady notes of alcohol, espresso, rum, all intermingles a creates a note that is slightly reminiscent of a coffee liquor.

The taste is fairly light up front, it would seem this beer has thinned out a bit over time.  The finish has a solid dark chocolate note that lingers on with a bit of that characteristic chocolate bitterness.  I think that the light oxidation has accentuated the chocolate note in the finish.  This beer is lightly sweet throughout, which, serves as a great foil for the noticeable roasted character.  There is a certain burn acidity, which in combination with the roasted grain note reminds me of an espresso shot.

The dark malts in this beer have allowed it to stand up quite well over the years.  The oxidation while apparent is still at the stage where it adds a bit to the complexity, and I think that it makes up quite well for the smoothing out and loss of complexity in the up front malt notes that would have been in this beer originally.  I also really like the boosted chocolate notes in this beer, the finish reminds me of vibrant cocoa powder in both its chocolate note and its bitterness.

Bottle Pours a dense black color and a tan head that is not particularly thick or creamy.  Lovely chocolate and pitted fruit aroma. A littel sourness and plenty of sweet dark roasted notes as well.
Flavor shows off more of the coffee taste and the slightly swet smokiness that I expected.  Feel is moderate and slightly dry for the style.  There is that sour flavor here as well and the lingering trailer is here the classic charcoal and coffee hints are more prevelant.  Carbonation is quite lively.  Not as slick on the palate as I was expecting or hoping for but tasty anyway.  Thanks to Styles for sending this one my way.

Formidable hiss as the cap comes off, pouring with moderate viscosity, opaque and black in color with a touch of lightening when put to light.  Wispy grey head with a complimentary rung around the corners.  Aroma is very much in tact.  Lactic chocolate and semi-sweet morsels melted on a dirty cookie sheet.  Touch of syrupy mochas and white chocolate covered raisins.  Coffee annotations resound most prominently in the flavor department.  Dry, bitter tract.  Sweetness comes in the form of dark chocolate Ghirardelli squares.  Some chocolate confectionary dust.  Dry, bitter-sweet palate serenade.  Not sure if its the age, but balance has achieve a perfect equilibrium.  Finish is laden with coffee grinds and cocoa powder with a bitter resonance at the outset.  Huge thanks to Styles for this one!

Thanks to Sully for this bonus beer.  Pours standard stout black color with large brown head.  The aroma is big.  Roasted and full malts.  Chocolate and sweetness and some dark fruit character.  Molasses and a discernable oatmeal aroma.  Great big roasted malt and coffee flavors.  Quite full and smooth.  Chalkey chocolate flavors followed by a pinch of alcohol and a roasty finish well after the final sip.

Pours dark brown nearly black, with decent tan head. Lots of shocolate and dark fruit up front with some faint coffee, Flavor very sweet, lots of chocolate, maybe some mollasses and again dark fruts. No idea on the age of the bottle, pre-02 is all I know, but this is still holding up well.

Light roastiness joins with sweet cocoa in the pleasantly inviting aroma.  Opaque black body with low tan-brown head that recedes to cover with some nice lacing.  Roasty bittersweet cocoa flavour is moderately bitter.  Medium body is quite dry and well attenuated with moderate carbonation.  Bottle sampled at DenverLogans GABF 2005 wrap-up.

On tap:  Strong roasted coffee aroma with moderate dark chocolate and cream.  Dark brown, virtually black, with no transparency and a small off-white head.  Lots of roasted coffee and grain up front.  Nice chocolate balance in the middle and a light pine finish.

Bottle from SuIIy. Aroma is restrained roasted malts, some oats, maybe slightly vineous. Pours very deep brown with a nice foamy head. A lot of weird floaties on the pour... weird floaties like Ive never seen. They were deep tan colored, not solid at all, almost looked alive... they seemed to have dissappeared though about a minute after the pour. Theyve left me a little worried/confused as no one else has mentioned them, but the thing tastes fine (I think), so I guess its not infected. 

Taste is roasty, almost smokey, with a touch of coffee. Not seeing much in the way of oats or sweetness. A very slight touch of bitterness at the end though no noticable hop tastes. Tastes mostly like a porter, to me.
Dark rich & very flavorful this ones a keeper!  No longer brewed but not soon forgoten.

Mucho Gracias to El Sully!!!  This one pours pitch black with a foamy brown head.  It smells very good.  The aroma is sugar and roasted malts.  The taste reminds me a lot of a local milk stout.  Sweet roasted malts at first with a mildly citrus/tangy finish.  Very smooth and oily mouthfeel.  Very well done.

Duane was so kind as to let me sample some of this beer.  Aroma of mainly coffee and roasted malts with some sweet sugary scents in there as well.  Flavor is coffee and some chocolate as well.  Another well made beer by Bells

12 oz. bottle from trade with Walleye, thanks Jim.  Once again another solid stout from the fine folks at Bells.  black on the pour with a tan head which settles down to superb lace on the inside of the snifter.  first whiff was of the customary dark roast malt and hints of cinnamon.  flavors are mostly coffee with some dark chocolate , licorice and hops on the tail end.  solid in every aspect.  glad I got the chance to drink this one.

1st of all I cannot believe that I found this. poured black, with a dark tan head. aroma , has soon as I opened this I could smell the chocolate and malts, oncce in the glass, the chocolate became the bittersweet  kind, roasted malts, molasses, coffee, brown sugar, raisins and got a hint of plums. flavor was not disappointed at, got dark sweet chocolate, malts, cherries, espresso. the mouth feel was nice and smooth, not too thick and not too thin. one of the better oatmeal stots I have had this aged very well.

Thanks to SuIIy for this 12 oz bottle.  Darkest dark color with a tan head that didnt last forever.  Aromas were very sweet malts; chocolate, coffee.  Flavors were roasty samples of the same with a very nice hop finish that made a good beer great.  Great Stuff.

12 oz bottle via trade with SuIIy - Thanks Mike - Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts,  coffeee, and a bit of licorice.  Flavor is much of the same. blended very well and there are still some remnants of hops at the finish.  Palate is full bodied.. The oatmeal must add to the body.   Nice flavor, nice palate, nice beer.  Glad I got the chance to try this one...

One word: Black. The beige head diminishes swiftly on top of it. Despite its age, mellow floral hops can be felt underneath the fruitiness, the latter reminding of blackberry and prune, but not quite in a vinous way. Medium creamy body, the carbonation is still engaging. Definitely starting to lose its character, but still an interesting and rather complex stout at 3 yrs of age, ripe in texture, distinctively oaty and dark in maltiness.

Thanks to Roberts Reality for this.  Pours deep blackish withy 1-finger tan head.  Aroma of roasty malt, chocoff, anise, and some cinnamon.  Tastes roasty dark malty, with chocoff, some licorice notes, and some lactosy oaty notes at the finish.  Solid heft on the palate.  It is my theory that this one was a dress rehearsal for the Special Double Cream stout.
Black, with a light brown head. Aromas are roasted malt and grain, and some chocolate. Flavors are roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.

Thanks to robertsreality for this beer.

Poured onyx with a semi-creamy brown head.  Aroma is sweet, with a touch of roasted chocolate and alcohol dryness.  Taste is lightly sweet with touches of coffee and chocolate.  Surprisngly bitter and dry finish.  Hoppier and drier than I expected from a Kalamazoo stout.  Thus this one seems too similar to other stouts and doesnt stand out as other Bells do.

12 oz bottle, vintage unknown. Black, oily pour with a small tan head. Rich toasted grains and coffee aromas. Taste is bittersweet chocolate, light oats, oak and espresso. Much better than I anticipated. Smooth body and nicely hopped.

Poured a dark brown, decent off white head. Very nice spotty lacing across. Aroma is somewhat sour, with oats, and licorice. Flavor is all oatmeal, a hint of chocolate and barley. Very awesome! Thanks to Chuck for this one!

Thanks Chuck!  Poured with a really thick rocky brown head even after the bottle was sitting for a half-hour.  There is excellent lacing upon this dark black body.  The aroma is much like you poured Quaker Oats into a vat of liquid chocolate and coffee.  The flavor is really quite nice even after 2 years.  The flavor is very much like a sweet stout should be.  Very chocolatey, coffee, grass hops, oatmeal.  The palate is full bodied and still pretty smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2009 poured a nice dark thick color w/ a good tan/brown head that laces very well.  Smell was of a nice sweet syruppy malt a bit of quaker oats and hints of alcohol and coffee or dry chocolate.  Good stuff.  Palate is a solid mouth feel and some good creaminess.  The flavor is a nice dry chocolate bitter finish w/ a good malt background.
** Had it again at GTMW maduro.. just such a fantastic Oatmeal stout..  I could drink this every day!
Black Coloring with Tan Skin.  Barley, Oats Aroma.  Dry Oats, Sweet, Syrapy and Strong Overall.  Solid Malt Background with Perhaps A Very Subtle Hit of Chocolate and Coffee. Very Nice Stout!

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2005 Opaque black/brown, nice thick pour, brownish head which diminished rather quickly.  Aromas of roasted malts, toffee, brown sugar, and subtle coffee and chocolate.  Flavor was that of bittersweet chocolate, coffee, malts with a dry lasting finish.  Quite sweet, more so than I like normally, but it worked here.  Very fine lacing.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2005 Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a fizzy light tan head. Nose is heavy on the  bittersweet chocolate. Taste is sweet with chocolate, raisins and plums. Palate is super fizzy and airy. ALmost a cherry taste in the finish

Black color with a thin head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Very lovely coffee presense and the oatmeal is blended in wonderfully.  Its much more dry than I would expect an oatmeal stout to be, but still very good.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 Bottle... Pitch black with a very creamy, light brown head. Terrific retention. Smoke, vanilla, chocolate, oak and a hint of bourbon in the nose.  The flavor is very hearty, chocolatey, vineous and smoky with a touch of toffee. Medium-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Lengthy, bone-dry finish. Thanks to jtw for sending me this very elusive brew!

Dusty 12oz bottle found in a liquor store in Duluth.  Dark brown to black body under a small-bubbled tan head.  Potato skin roasty aroma with milk chocolate and cream cheese.  Fairly dry flavor that has lots of oily black malt and what seems like tart oatmeal.  Tart grain husk finish.  This beer is on its last legs but still exhibits some of what its original character probably was like.

Obtained in a trade with CharlesDarwin. Deep, opaque black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and a ton of chocolate syrup, bakers chocolate and ovaltine. Taste has big notes of chocolate and roasted malt along with some nuttiness, coffee and malted milk balls. Perfect amount of sweetness - just delicious. Roasty, milkshake-like finish. Mouthfeel is full, round and smooth with subtle carbonation. Not much lacing but great head retention. Just awesome all around.

Nice brown color,small tan head that faded slowly and left a bit of a lace behind.The aroma was pleasant.Nice malty flavor with a slight creamy side from the oatmeal i imagine and a little chocolate coming through in the middle.The brew comes off as being kind of sweet with a nice chocolate side.Much better then there regular stout and definatley a brew that i want to keep around for every day.

Light brown decent head with good lacing. Tar black. Wafts of fresh earth and leather, backed by strong berry aroma. An almost, smoked, burnt pine nut finish. Very light carbonation. Very sweet, yet sour and salty. Lingering lemon and grapes on the palata. Not too dry or too creamy. Nice balance. Alcohol is perfectly blended.
Pours black with creamy tanish head.  Nose is creamy, somewhat chololatey and malty.  Flavor is complex, smooth with roasted malt character.  Finishes with smooth, milky dry effect.
on draft at the eccentric cafe in kalamazoo.  looks, smells, and tastes much like a starchy version of the kalamazoo stout.  very good, but the kalamazoo stout is better as a flagship stout.
chocolate aroma, medium tan head nice flavor with good bitter aftertaste. roasted flavor comes through nicely
Pours pure black color with a lingering tan head. Smells of chocolate malt and  sweetness.  A very hearty brew.  Sweet and smooth with a roasty chocolate finish.  Nice!
Black with a large head. Flavour is roasted malt and creamy texture expected in a oatmeal stout. Sweet and tasty with a dry finish.

Of Kalamazoo's November stouts, only Rye, Cherry, and Java have actual label designs, with all the others wrapped in generic black and white. Guys, would a smiling, dancing bag of oats be all that hard to do?

Solid black, with an enormous, towering tan head. Roasty aromas stand triumphant, with hints of spices, anise, cloves, espresso...no, more like immersing your entire face into a steaming pile of coffee grounds. Earthy, but soft on the palate, with an initial rush of gritty texture. Long and satisfying finish, dry, full, substantial. Medium/full-bodied, and,mmmmm..excuse me,...mmmmm, oh,yeah! The flavor keeps on giving and giving! 

This might go down as my favorite American oatmeal stout! If we can get KBC to brew it year-round, I'll get to work on Oaty the Happy Oatmeal Boy, and then we'll be in business!
Excellent flavor, but a little lighter than I was expecting.  This is a close second for me after Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout.  Nice and dark and wonderful mellowing with the oatmeal flavors.

Look Eric, I’m finally getting around to rating this beer after only 6 months in my cellar, Thank You very much for the trade! 
Black as a smoking kettle of tar with a head of coco. The stout lie tranquil as the rocky toffee head sloooooly recedes.  The aroma is in true form, mocha and grains, certainly pick up on the oatmeal here. 
DO I dare to touch my unholy lips to such a savory brew? Hell Yah I DO!
 Big heaps of espresso hit first, followed by a bourbon spiciness. The Oatmeal sneaks in right before a pressed Columbian coffee bean nails me with another blast of bitterness. Mocha, sweet cream, espresso, Mocha, sweet cream, espresso, are the ingredients that narrate this story; then PEEK, Oatmeal, bourbon, smoke and peat. 
 The palate is as smooth and full as chocolate fondue, exquisite! Finish is dry and tart, Really a Fantastic Beer!

Dark brown.Creamy,small bubbled,head. Leaves nice lace. Very oaty,creamy aroma. Roasty,chocolate underneath.Mouthfeel is creamy,medium body. Excellent oat,roasty,chocolate flavors. Finish is bitter,slightly sweet. The best of the retired stouts.

Lively foamy pour, dense dark body, chocolate mousse foam. Creamy, vanilla milkshake and charred aroma. Sweet fruity flavors in the palate, intense raisin and chocolate, followed by a heavily roasted (almost smokey) hazelnut, chocolate and coffee finish.

Nice, blackish dark brown appearance.  Decent head.  Aroma strongly of black patent malt, a touch burnt, with a chocolate backing.  Milk chocolate flavors come through, along with a balancing bitterness from the malts.  A bit roasty, good mouthfeel.  Also has that ethereal thing that floats around in oatmeal stouts that I can never quite put my finger on.  Maybe it is a mental thing, I would never be willing to bet I could recognize it blind.  But I would always recognize this as a fine beer.  Big props to Indra!

1 Year old.  Intense chocolate  and tell-tale oatmeal aroma.   Vinous and  tart upon my lips, but quickly faded to sweet, rich, creamy goodness.  Long sweet malt flavors fade slowly to a creamy, oatmealy and slightly bitter finish.

This bottle is now a year old.  Jet Black, fully carbonated.  Pours with a large head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma of malts, deep enough to have almost Merlot type qualities.  The flavor is burnt roasted up front with some carmel on the back end.  Mouthfell is creamy and full bodied.  Fair amount of bitterness on the finish.  Fine Stout though.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2005 2002 bottle sampled 10/7/2003.  Pours a deep black with some tinges of chestnut brown.  Medium-sized burnt beige head and lots of sediment.  Smells quite roasty, with alcohol and some sweet malt flavor apparent. Lots of lacing.
Begins quite dry, medium bitter and acidic.  Lots of roasted malt right away. Only after warming does the beer even out and a sweeter more expected flavor comes out.  Lots of peppery hops and a bakers chocolate flavor as well.  Finish is more smooth with some mildly sweet toffe coming out and a medium coffee roast flavor.  Quite unique as far as many other oatmeals.  Definitely a lot drier, but still a great flavor.  Medium to full body.  The finish is great, creamy yet not very sweet, creating a very true, roasty stout-like flavor that is not harsh.02 in 2004  After giving this one another year to age, it has proved to be close to perfect.  Lightly sweet, with some sticky chocolate malt, low carbonation, vanilla beans, light caramel flavors and finishing with a perfectly genuine coffee flavor.  Perfect palate, great aroma (prunes, chocolate, lots of medium roast coffee).02 in 2005. . . and this beer just continues to wow me.  I really feel like you have to have had the beer young to appreciate how well it has aged.  Silky, oily, vinous, tons of oats and chocolate with subdued black malt character and of course, a perfect mouthfeel.  Earthy roasted barley lingers on the aftertaste, with prunes, grapes and raisins.  Superb.

Aroma of chocolate cookie, roasty espresso, toffee and some background fruity, citrusy hop.  Deep brown-black color, still translucent, with a fine, creamy and lasting tan head.  Highly roasted malt profile, plenty of coffee bean, burnt grain and cocoa notes.  The citrusy, faintly floral and decidedly bitter hoppiness noted in the aroma becomes more prominent towards the finish, blending with the already bitter roasty malt to create a very dry effect.  Long, lingering roasty aftertaste.  Medium-full bodied.  A fairly thick and satisfying brew.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2006 RERATE: On tap at Eccentric Cafe:  Seems to have a more lactic twang and very heavy with the black malts than the richer oats. It was a letdown and thinner in body than I was expecting. (-1 Aroma, -1 Flavor, and -2 overall)
Ever so slightly lighter hue than the Kalamazoo Stout I just finished, the head on this brew is just a little more creamy and slighty better lacing. Now this smells like a sweet stout! Major chocolate and caramel tones with coffee, raisin, pecan, and oats. Sublime alcohol undertone detected by the nose as well. Taste was like biting into a bittersweet chocolate bar followed by a gulp of strong coffee. Chewy, creamy, lush mouthfeel, then dry lightly buttery finish. Hint of smoke in this one too, but not as strong as the forementioned stout. Once again, another quality stout from Bells, rate above Kzoo Stout and below Expedition and Double Cream.

Velvety smooth chocolate aroma with a coal black appearance.  Sports a mocha colored head - just a bit thin; but with good lacing. Coffee notes are prominent in the flavor with a bit of hoppy bitterness in the finish. Good thick creamy mouthfeel.

pours thick and black, beige head.  big aroma of coffee, roast and chocolate covered raisins.  lots of roast and mocha with a semi-tart almost port like mouthfeel.  roasty, bitter and slightly smoky finish.  very nice stout.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2003 Pours dark and thick as expected.  Light caramel head.  Aroma of chocolate, cinamon and nuts.  Delicious. Beautiful aftertaste that keeps on evolving on your tongue.  Flavours of licorice and smoke.  The only question is "should I eat it with a fork or a spoon?"

Tan, creamy head.  Diminishing at a medium rate.  Black in color, light fights to get through the glass, but fails.  A little bit of a ruby hue.  Slightly roasty malt/chocolate aroma.  I'm not certain, but I think I can smell a fair amount of alcohol even though it's only at 5.7%.  Roasty coffee and oatmeal in the flavor, a little bitter/acidic, but I'm questioning if it comes from the hops or malts.  Another tastey concoction from Bells.

Pungent coffee, molasses aroma that is slightly more restrained then the previous Bell's Stout that I tried. Monstrous foamy tan head. Pouring results in cascading effect; Beer is opaque black. Palate is slightly thin up front, more maltier at the end. Quite dry and not as sweet as I expected. Alcohol is present at the end, and detectable hops, resulting is a slight harshness. In my opinion not as enjoyable as the Kalamazoo Stout. Still satisfying and above average.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2003 Poured out of bottle, bought at Hopleaf bar in Chicago, 5/3/03.  Extremely roasty.  Light coffee/chocolate aroma.  Not much head, doesn't hold.  Dark brown body with a hint of redness.  Smooth and luscious texture, but not a strong opening flavor; however. . . the proof is in the finish-- amazingly long, very strong coffee flavor.  This beer is all about the finish, and it's nice to sit back and savor it, but don't look for much other excitement along the way.  High quality stout, but I've had others with more going on.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 Light aroma of a very heavy smell mixed with coffee and chocolate. My initial pour yielded a very small head of small dark brown bubbles that quickly disappeared. It's body was made up of a deep ruby red opaque color. My initial taste response was one of coffee and thick flavor. It went down somewhat smoothly but left behind a slight after bite. One of the better stouts I have had, but still not overly impressive.

Aroma is malt, coffee, hazelnut, and chocolate.  Dark, dark brown color with a decent dark brown head.  The first thing that jumps out in the flavor is a roasted character, followed by a smooth maltiness with notes of hazelnut and chocolate.  The balance is pretty close to even, neither bitter or sweet.  Very full body, almost chewy.  About what I expect of an oatmeal stout from a quality brewery.

I dont know that I would have picked this out from the typical stouts, not that it isnt good, just that it isnt especially distinctive.  I really did pick up oatmeal, along with a healthy dose of vanilla and hazelnut in the aroma.  The flavor is balanced, with oatmeal riding shotgun with that Bells all-around stout composition, roasted and smooth, not especially hoppy or bitter.  Gets a decent head, looks the part of a stout, and the flavors match.

Pours a jet black color with a lingering, small, tan head. Strong aroma of chocolate malts and oatmeal sweetness with a touch of roastiness in the background. Thick, rich, and velvety smooth, the flavor is all malts and oatmeal with hints of chocolate and a burnt bitterness in the finish. Creamy and delicious, this is an excellent oatmeal stout.

Thick, black with lots of chunks … the appearance is a facsimile of good oatmeal itself.  Creamy, buttery head.  The aroma is similar to java mocha being brewed when you walk into a coffee house from the cold.  The aroma is belied by the first sip which contains loads (more than anticipated) roasted malts.  The texture has all the creaminess expected from an oatmeal, but there is a note of astringency that doesn’t fit.  This beer, however, deserves a good rating for its aroma alone.  A nice mid-winter brew.
A thin, overcarbonated and pretty much disappointing brew from such a wonderful brewery.  Pass me a Sam Smith anyday.

A nice, smooth stout.  The roasted flavors aren't as distinct in this one as they are in the other Bells stouts.  This one does have a nice smooth, creamy feel, however.  I would still suggest one of Bells regular stouts (Kalamazoo Stout or Double Cream Stout) over any of the November stouts.

lord.  these kalamazoo folk got stouts like b.b.'s got the blues.  they got a dandelion stout and a chittlin' and hambone stout and a toe jam mustard  stout--all of 'em about ten bucks a six pack!  this one's worth it. it's black. ordinary light knows well it's limitations and wisely just steps around this obsidian pour. i'd use a glass of this for viewing the next solar eclipse, but i imagine i'd miss the action. a blooming head of camel-suede color causes it to ace the 'appearance' category.  nutty aroma, baker's chocolate, straw broom and cantaloupe, all nicely configured. carbonation evolves to creaminess, it's full bodied, lightly sweet, darkened grains without being roasted, it's currants and unsweetened cocoa powder. good hop bitterness, and some slight chalkiness in the finish.  tho i can't  tell oatmeal from oyster shells generally,  this is a fine stout.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2003 definately a pleasant suprise to see this on tap at old chicago in rockford, IL-this beer is the replacement for two hearted on their tap.  I ordered this brew with some hesitation since i didn't think the bells stout was that great.  This had a great aroma, taste was carmal and coffee malt all wraped up with some oats.  The finish lasted for a long time, especially when i left the place and the cold air got into the mix-ummmmmm!!!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2003 This is a good stout, but as far as Bell's stouts go, its pretty average.  Dark color, brown/tan head, smells like roasted coffee, but not as much as the kalamazoo stout does.  The flavor is dark chocolate, oats, and a general presence of roastyness. Its worth a try, but if you havent tried their expedition or double cream stouts yet, I'd suggest giving them a try first.
A very dark beer, nice and think.  Full bodied without too much bite.  A much better value that Sam Smith's.

Very dark pour, medium  head, toasty aroma is light, almost hard to find. Full bodied yet quite smooth from start to finish, can't really fault it except to say that the flavors are a bit too subdued to make a lasting impression. A very decent stout but not the best.
Beautiful deep brown pour with a nice tan head.  Wonderful coffee, chocolate and toasted oat aroma and flavorings.  Not as good as the Bells Expedition stout, but a good runner up.

I missed reviewing this one, even though I have had a few of them before. This beer poured as black as sin and formed a light tan foamy head that left circular lace as it subsided. An aroma of malt, oats, burnt coffee and chocolate. A flavor of malt, burnt coffee and chocolate. It had a medium body and a slightly astrigent finish.

Pours black as night with a sweet roasted aroma with some nuttiness.  Great full-bodied flavor with a warming toasty finish.  This rivals St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout.  Another one of Bells' great beers.

Bell's doesn't have the most inspiring labeling, but it's what's inside that counts, right? Pours a deep dark brown with a medium and lasting beige head. Decent lacing. Aroma is very roasty with some oat smell too. The flavor is not as sweet and creamy as many Oatmeal Stouts, it was actually a little dry. Flavors of espresso, chocolate, and a little malt lent to a smooth finish. Very good.
Deep brown color, almost like expresso. Nice roaster flavor with a long finish. I will look for this again on the next trip back to MI.
Bottle.  Black color with a touch of ruby at the corner.  An impressive foamy brown head.  A load of malts jump into the nose and sweetness lingers.  Bitter chocolate and some burnt character.

Solid in every way, but I cant find anything about it to distinguish it from the pack of bells stouts.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel, moderate hoppiness (more subdued than many of the other bells stouts) good balance between roast, chocolate and sweetness.  Good, but not distinguished.
Yummy stuff. I like this one with a stew.
UPDATED: MAY 13, 2003 Very dark brown with a brown head. Roasted oats and chocolate aroma. Roasted malt flavor. Bitter somewhat metallic finish.
Excellent, full bodied stout. Roasted aroma and mild chocolate flavor. Goes down well.
Fresh, sweet brown sugar aroma.  Good roasty flavor, hoppy, hints of licorice.  Long finish, blends beautifully, very nice oatmeal stout.
Comes across as a dry stout with a mild twist. Roastiness is dominate flavor and oatmeal seems to do little but soften the beer a bit. Otherwise it might be a bit harsh.
Black with nice brown lace around the glass.  Roast coffee aroma.  Very smooth with a mellow coffee bitterness and a nice clean finish.
Excellent deep and dark as an abyss.  The oatmeal is not in your face but subtle and really adds character.
Dark brown almost black color, decent tan head. Sweet chocolate burnt aroma, chocolate cocoa powder and light coffee coffee flavors, nice smooth and creamy mouthfeel.
Big milk chocolate nose. Sweet and creamy flavor. This is a delicious stout. Excellent brew! Thanks to hopsrus for this one!

What would happen if you had some instant oatmeal and added hot coffee instead of water, dust with cocoa powder: Ferment and serve!  This is deeeeelicious!  Not as overly sweet as some oat-stouts, this has some roasted flavors and a nice dryness.
a deep dark brown with large tan head, aroma is roasted chocolate malt with a hint of coffee, sweet and smooth with taste of cholate and coffee, nice bitter hop finish.

Bottle.  Bubbly based head with creamy top.  Off-white to brown in color.  The beer itself is black.  Good head lacing with a semilasting head.  Average density and easy to drink.  Roasted burnt aroma and flavor.  Tiny yeastiness, oat, vanilla and chocolate milk.  Smooth and slightly sweet. Coffee and toffee finish. Recommended.

Oh man. This is perhaps the perfect example of my favorite kind of beer. Full oats and chocolate aroma. The flavor was very chocolaty...very sweet...like a creamy chocolate milk shake. I too, tasted a cashew-like nutty flavor which blended perfectly with the other flavors. Not really much bitterness here. This beer is all about the malty sweetness. Nice roasted character with its milk chocolate core, and oatmeal creaminess. Perfectly black color...thick tan head, and perfect carbonation.
Very dark brown w/ a 2 finger tan head. Some oats & cocoa in the nose. A bit more carbonated than I like, but it does have a nice smoothness about it.

pours an opaque black, with a decent beige head. aroma is fairly yeasty (strangely reminding me of sour milk, but not in a bad way) with a hint of coffee. flavors are coffee with a fair hop quality...slight bitterness....not too shabby

while the aroma of this beer is not overly powerful, it definitely has some malty notes with a coffe scent.  there is the faint smell of candy.  the flavor follows in the same manner.  a faint sweetness with a coffee malt flavor.  it is a very drinkable stout, and i dont usually enjoy stouts.  very good almost comparable to a guiness.
Deliciously dry roasted, bitter coffee/espresso with a hint of sweetness.   Leaves a mouthfeel like I was just eating oats.   Chocolately bitter finish.

A great oatie.  I found it very refreshing that this one wasnt all sugared up like Sammy Smith. This was the last November Stout I needed to try before I tried them all.  Since there are 6 of them, Bells should sell a "november stout" six pack with one of each kind in it.

Im not sure how I missed this one last year, but it wont happen again.  Phenomenal build to this stout, it feels layered in the mouth with each layer a bold assertion of dark goodness, from the full oat sweets to the roasted edges, from the rich nut (cashew) tones to the swift hop bitters on close.  Finishes dry like the effect of eating freshly shelled pecans.  Admirable stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 Draft:  Traditional Bell"s rocky, dense, and sticky foam.  Lovely velvety bottle conditioned mouthfeel.  Gargantuan toasted peanut aroma blanketed by charcoal, cardboard, oats, gelatin, and some underlying mocha.  Full of chocolate, peanut, and graham.  Finishes both intensely roasty and burnt with bitter chocolate and a notable dryness.  The best American made Oatmeal Stout I have yet tasted.   November is the best month of the year!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: As a style, I really like Oatmeal Stouts.  They are like having a beer meal.  This one is very good.  As good as Rouges Shakespheare?  Almost.  Pours out to a deep black.  Taste is that of roasted malt with that oatmeal sweetness.  Delicious.

This was the first sweet stout where I really noticed the sweetness of it.  Poured thick and dark, but not opaque.  Smelled of intense sweet chocolate.  Flavor was quite similar.  Very smooth and refreshing, but as the bottle wore on, it became a bit too sweet for me.
Very dark brown.  Cocoa and oats aromas.  Not as silky as some oatmeal stouts.  Fairly dry hoppy finish.  These stouts of November were really fun.

Almost black but not opaque. Decent,thin tan head and lace. Nose is roasted oats and malts. Creamy mouthfeel, a bit thin but has a nice almost rich body. Mildly roasty palate with interplays of oats and a touch of metal.  Moderatley smooth and hoppy finish that is tasty. Good beer. Thank you Prof!
Opaque black with beige head. Roasty, creamy but somewhat dry. Full bodied and well balanced. Like strong coffee with cream and sugar. Thanks PsychProf!

Extremely dark brown, but yeah Im still getting a tiny bit of light through there.  Hints of oats right away in the aroma, then lots of roast; slightly metallic palate, some roastiness, lacking the smoothness I was hoping for.

Dark brown with a healthy tan head. Heavy carb for a stout, although expected because of the bottle conditioning.Roasted malts and oaty nose. Light body initially with dark cocoa, light roast and oaty sweetness. Nicely flavored although a wee bit thin for my liking. Not a knockout brew but a solid example. Thanks Trap.

Deep brown to black color, the beige head and sheet lace are cocoa brown. Nose is high in oat tones, the start malt sweet, the top is full, sweet, creamy and rich. Nice toasted finish, that has a decent hop presence, damn fine beer, thanks Trap.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 Theres something really rich in the finish of this beer. I love oatmeal cookies, so this report is biased. Theres a good balance here, and I like it more than regular K-Zoo Stout.

roasted oats aroma making me think of Roffeys stout, only weaker.  absent of that soy oatmeal flavor ive come to love from sam smith.  small oatmeal flavor balanced with a nice oaty malty taste.  excellent stout

Dark brown ale with ruby hints and a small tan head.   The beer produces a slightly roasted aroma.   Oily and just a little chewy, the moutfeel matches what Ive come to expect from this style.   Bells take on an Oatmeal Stout finishes with a bit of a hop bitter which is somewhat unusual.   The flavor is a nice toasty malt with mild chocolate whispers.   Very good as a standalone specimen; but paling in comparison to the other Bells stouts.
Good oatmeal stout, more drinkable for a multiple stout session than the other Bells breakfast stout.
I just cant find a whole lot outstanding about this. Really an average stout for Bells whcih is still better than most, but just not amazing.

This one is similar too, but better than their Susies Sweet Stout.  Superb chocolate/oatie aroma, and a nice sweet, mellow flavour, with just the right amount of bitter hop flavpour towards the end.  Well done!!

A bit of a thicker stout from this brewery, excellent malt flavor with somewhat of a bizarre smokey chocolate aftertaste. An excellent beer aside from the lingering bitter chocolate aftertaste, not as smooth as some of the worlds better oatmeal stouts.
Very good, complex and full bodied. Definitly a sipping beer.
Bells does it again. Great roasted chocolate and coffee flavor that stays with you.
Larry Bell did it again.  This is one GREAT stout.  Its rich and flavorful.  Virtually no head, but its still a great stout.  Get it before its gone!
